(a) Co 2p X-ray photoemission spectra of NP, NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS (the lines represent: black - best fit line; grey - XPS data; red - Co2+; blue – Co2+ satellite; maroon – Co-O-Si). (b) Si 2p X-ray photoemission spectra of NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS referenced against Stöber’s silica spheres (the lines represent: black - best fit line; grey - XPS data; purple - background; dashed brown – Si-OH; Green - Si-O-Si; maroon - Co-O-Si; yellow- Si-C, pink - Si-C with reduced silane (or Si-H). (c) C 1 s X-ray photoemission spectra of NP, NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS (the lines represent: black - best fit line; grey - XPS data; purple- baseline; dashed green– CO; dashed red – C-O; dashed blue – CC and yellow- Si-C). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Infrared spectra of the unmodified and silane-modified cobalt oxide NPs after reduction in H2 at 573 K for 8 hrs (the lines represent: black – NP; Maroon – NP-TEOS; Navy Blue- NP-TPES; Yellow – NP-TMCS). An inset indicates the FTIR spectrum of NP-TEOS in the zoomed region of 2400–4000 cm−1. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Influence of the modification of cobalt oxide NPs with different silanes on CO adsorption and catalytic activities. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) Activity of the different SiC-supported (modified) Co-NPs in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis after reduction in H2 at 573 K for 16 hrs. (b) TOF of NP, NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS supported on β-SiC plotted as a function of the ratio of dissociative CO/associative CO obtained from TPD results (see Table 5). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Ratio of 1-olefin/n-paraffin in the Fischer-Tropsch product as a function of chain length (in the region C2-C5) after 44 hrs on stream for the different model catalyst. Catalysis Institute, Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Cape Town Private Bag X3, Rondebosch 7701 South Africa Cobalt oxide (CoO) nanoparticles (NPs) were modified with different silanes (tetraethoxysilane – TEOS, triphenyl ethoxysilane – TPES, or trimethyl chlorosilane - TMCS) by dispersing the as-synthesized CoO NPs in n-hexane solutions containing the silanes. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) confirmed the presence of these silanes on the cobalt surfaces even after reduction in hydrogen (H2) at 573 K. Modifying CoO-NPs with TEOS resulted in face-centred cubic (fcc)-cobalt phase upon reduction whereas TPES or TMCS modification induced a mixture of hexagonal close-packed (hcp)- and fcc-cobalt phases. The modification of cobalt surfaces with the silanes alters the adsorption properties of carbon monoxide (CO) on the catalytically active sites. Furthermore, temperature programmed desorption of CO (CO-TPD) showed that the amount of dissociatively adsorbed CO relative to amount of associatively adsorbed CO increases on silane-modified cobalt surfaces, which correlates with an improved rate of CO conversion in the Fischer-Tropsch CO hydrogenation. Graphical Abstract Keywords CoO nanoparticles Modification Silanes Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Data Availability all data has been included in the manuscript 1 Introduction Cobalt (Co)-based nanoparticles (NPs) have shown to have outstanding catalytic properties in a variety of chemical reactions such as CO hydrogenation [1], CO oxidation [2], and hydroamination of alcohols [3]. The intrinsic activity of Co NPs as catalysts in these reactions depends on both their electronic properties and their physical properties including size, morphology, and crystal structure. The ability of metallic cobalt NPs to adsorb and dissociate CO makes them suitable for their application in CO hydrogenation via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The strength of adsorption of specific adsorbates e.g., CO, on the surface of these nanomaterials is determined by the surface properties of the metals, which may be tuned. Modification of the catalyst surface with organometallic ligands is a relatively new approach in the field of nanotechnology aiming to tune surface properties of catalytically active materials [1,4–7]. The introduced ligands determine the ultimate interaction of the NPs with their surroundings and surface modification of NPs may improve thermal stability, mechanical strength and hinder sintering [1,8–10]. Furthermore, the hydrophilicity of NPs may be altered by attaching hydrophobic ligands to the NPs [1,11]. Modification of NPs does not only alter the physical properties of the modified NPs, but may also affect the electronic properties of the sites to which the ligand is bonded [12]. This electronic influence may not be restricted to the surface atom to which the ligand is bonded but may also alter atoms surrounding the sites occupied by the ligand. Consequently, the catalytic properties of such adjacent, ligand-free surface atoms may change as well. The change in the electronic properties may thus alter the heat of adsorption of the reactants and affect the rate of the catalysed reaction.[13] Introduction of ligands on a metal surface may be thought to be detrimental in the context of catalysis as they may lower the adsorption capacity by covering the adsorption sites. However, surface modification of metals is used to fine-tune the properties of the catalyst, with the aim to increase the activity and selectivity. Recently, we have shown [10,14] that modifying cobalt oxide (Co3O4) results in the formation of Co-O-Si bonds yielding silicate islands on the particle. The performance of this material in its reduced state, enhanced the catalytic activity in CO hydrogenation whilst reducing the selectivity slightly towards the formation of methane. Here, we compare a novel approach by examining the modification of Co(II)O with various silanes (tetraethoxysilane-TEOS, triphenyl ethoxysilane – TPES and trimethyl chlorosilane TMCS) and report on their effect on the catalytic performances of the reduced, modified cobalt oxide in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Notably, our investigation represents a pioneering contribution as we delve into the unexplored territory of elucidating electronic effects arising from ligands containing electron-donating groups, such as the OH-groups, phenyl ring or methyl groups. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials All chemicals used in this study were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Cobalt carbonyl (Co2(CO)8) was used as a metal precursor while both dioctylamine (DOA, 97 %) and oleic acid (OLEA, 90 %) were used as co-surfactants. Dichlorobenzene served as a high-boiling point solvent. Mixtures containing absolute ethanol, acetone, methanol, or chloroform were used for settling, cleaning, and redispersing of cobalt nanoparticles (NPs) after synthesis. n-Hexane was used as a solvent during the modification process. Silanes (tetraethoxysilane – TEOS, triphenyl ethoxysilane – TPES and trimethyl chlorosilane – TMCS) were used to modify the cobalt surface. β-SiC (SiCAT) was utilised as a support material for the dispersion of cobalt NP. Carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2) gases (AFROX) used as feed for the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. No additional purification was performed on the chemicals before use. 2.2 Synthesis of cobalt nanoparticles (NPs) Cobalt NPs (22–28 nm) were synthesized by decomposition of a cobalt carbonyl [Co2(CO)8] [15]. In the synthesis, 1.08 g Co2(CO)8, oleic acid (0.5 mL) and dioctylamine (5.0 mL) were mixed with dichlorobenzene (60 mL) at 333 K. Upon complete dissolution of Co2(CO)8, the temperature was raised to 453 K at a rate of 10 K/min to initiate the decomposition of the carbonyl precursor. The reaction temperature was kept constant for 15 min. After the formation of a grey precipitate, the obtained hot suspension was contacted with absolute ethanol (50 mL). The precipitate was washed several 5 times with absolute ethanol (200 mL). The powder was recovered by evaporating ethanol in open air in a fume-hood overnight. 2.3 Synthesis of SiO2 Stöber spheres Silica spheres were synthesized using the Stöber’s method [16]. A solution containing tetraethoxysilane in ethanol was added to a known amount of water and refluxed at 348 K for 10 hours in the presence of ammonium hydroxide which acted as a hydrolysis catalyst. The resulting silica particles were washed with ethanol and distilled water and calcined at 573 K for 2 hours. 2.4 Modification of the NPs with silanes The as-synthesized cobalt NPs were re-dispersed in n-hexane at room temperature, yielding a suspension with a solid concentration of 1.4 g/L. Silanes (TEOS, TPES or TMCS) were added to the suspension and the initial concentration of silane in these suspensions was similar. After contacting the solid with the stirred solution (300 rpm), the solid was recovered by centrifugation and washed 5 times each with 50 mL of n-hexane. The contact time was varied to obtain the deposition of a similar quantity of silanes on the NPS with a targeted molar ratio of Si Co targeted = 30 mmol/mol. The resultant modified samples were dried by evaporation of the solvent in open air. The unmodified sample was contacted with pure n-hexane and treated in the same manner as the modified NPs with the only difference being the presence of silane in the solution. 2.5 Catalyst preparation After repeated washing, the obtained (un)modified NPs were supported on to β-SiC microspheres (SiCAT, dparticle= 100 μm, SBET = 25 m2/g, Vpore = 0.30 cm3 /g) by sonicating 0.1 g of the (modified) oxide together with 0.9 g of β-SiC microspheres in 50 mL of chloroform for 1 hr. The solvent was subsequently removed by evaporation at room temperature. The supported material was subsequently washed with acetone and allowed to dry in a fume-hood for 4 hrs. 2.6 Characterization The morphology of the NPs was analysed using a JEM200CX (JEOL, JAPAN) transmission electron microscope (TEM), operating at 120 kV. The phase composition of the NPs was determined using a Bruker AXS D8 Advance X-ray laboratory diffractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA utilizing a Co source (λCo-Kα = 0.178897 nm) and a VÅNTEC position-sensitive detector. The silicon loading of the NPs was determined using energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX) on a scanning electron microscope (LEO S444 SEM) equipped with a Four Quadrant Back Scatter Detector and an energy dispersive Fissons Kevex X-ray spectrometer. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the unsupported (modified) samples reduced in H2 at 573 K for 8 hrs and subsequently passivated with CO2 were acquired at room temperature and with an overall energy resolution of 0.6 eV, using a SPECS PHOIBOS 150 hemispherical electron energy analyser and a monochromatized Al Kα photon source (hν = 1486.71 eV). Charging of the sample surface was counteracted by means of a low-energy flood gun (electron energy = 2 eV, electron flux = 20 μA). An FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet 5700) was used to determine the state of the modifying agent ( Si Co ∼ ca. 30 mmol/mol) on the surface of the NPs after reduction. The obtained (un)modified NPs (0.1 g) were reduced in hydrogen (H2) (5 mL/min) at 573 K for 8 hrs. After reduction, the sample temperature was decreased to room temperature in helium (He). The reduced unsupported (modified) sample was immediately transferred to a glove box operating under inert N2 gas at a pressure of 1.5 bars and prepared by instantly diluting 1.0 mg of the samples with 0.2 g of potassium bromide (KBr) and then pressed into translucent pellets. A total of 32 scans were taken in the range of 400 – 4000 cm−1 for each reduced sample. The reduction behaviour of the supported catalysts was studied using temperature programmed reduction (TPR), performed on an AutoChem2950 (Micromeritics Instrument Corp., USA). The sample (ca. 0.1 g) was degassed at 393 K in flowing argon (Ar) (50 mL (NTP)/min) for 1 hr. The temperature was subsequently decreased to 340 K, followed by a change in gas composition to 5 vol% H2/Ar keeping the flowrate at 50 mL (NTP)/min. The temperature was increased linearly from 340 K to 1173 K at 10 K/min. The degree of reduction of the supported catalyst was determined for all samples by reducing the catalyst in H2 at 573 K for 8 hrs. After cooling the sample in Ar, the reduced samples were reduced further in a temperature programmed mode by ramping the temperature by 10 K/min in a gas mixture of 5 % H2 in Ar. The degree of reduction was computed from the relative H2 consumption of the reduced catalyst to that required for complete reduction of CoO. The activation energy (Ea) and pre-exponential factor (A) for the reduction process were determined by fitting the reduction peaks using a unimolecular decay model, thus assuming first-order reaction kinetics for the reduction process. Temperature programmed desorption of CO (CO-TPD) from the supported catalyst was performed in a 1 cm I.D. quartz reactor in an AutoChem2929 (Micrometics Instrument Corp., USA). The catalyst was crushed into a fine powder and loaded into the quartz reactor. The catalysts were subsequently reduced in H2 (40 mL (NTP)/min) at 573 K for 8 hrs (with aramp rate of 10 K/min). The system was subsequently cooled down to 383 K in He. CO was injected into the He flow (50 mL (NTP)/min (15 times with 0.053 mmol CO/g Co per dose). The temperature of the system was subsequently increased using a linear ramp of 10 K/min to 1223 K in He (50 mL (NTP)/min), while monitoring the change in the thermal conductivity of the effluent using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The dispersion of cobalt in the supported catalysts was determined using H2 chemisorption at 398 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 using the static volumetric method. The sample holder was loaded with 0.5 g of sample sandwiched between two layers of glass wool. The sample holder was degassed at 383 K overnight to remove any adsorbed moisture. The catalyst was reduced in situ for 8 hours at 573 K with H2. Following the reduction, H2 was removed from the system using He as a purge gas prior to evacuation and measuring the isotherm. 2.7 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was carried out in a fixed bed reactor system. The model catalysts (0.1 g modified or unmodified cobalt oxide/0.9 g β-SiC) was diluted with silicon carbide (dparticle = 200–500μm) and loaded into the isothermal zone of the reactor. Catalyst activation was carried out through H2 reduction (40 mL (NTP/min) at 1 bar and 473 K (heating rate: 5 K/min) for 16 hrs. After catalyst activation, the catalyst is cooled down to 493 K in argon. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was carried out at 493 K, 20 bar, (H2:CO)inlet=2 and FCO,0/W = 5.23 mmol/(min.g Co) for 44 hrs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and modification of cobalt nanoparticles (NPs) Cobalt NPs were synthesized by the decomposition of cobalt carbonyl [15]. Fig. 1(a) shows representative transmission electron microscopy bright field (TEM-BF) images and the corresponding powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of these highly monodisperse CoO NPs. The cobalt size distribution was modelled using a log-normal distribution with an average diameter size of 26.1 nm (σ = 2.3 nm). Analysis of the crystalline structure using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) indicates that these cobalt NPs oxidized to form a Co(II)O phase upon exposure to air. The average crystallite domain sizes estimated from PXRD data using the Debye-Scherrer equation gave average crystallite domains of 23.3 nm and this size value is slightly smaller than that estimated from TEM images, suggesting highly monodisperse nanostructures. The as-synthesized CoO NPs were re-dispersed in n-hexane, yielding a suspension with a solid concentration of 1.4 g/L. Silanes (tetraethoxysilane – TEOS, triphenyl ethoxysilane – TPES, or trimethyl chlorosilane - TMCS) were added to the suspensions at room temperature; the initial concentrations of silane in the final suspension was varied to obtain a similar silicon loading of ca. 30 mmol Si/mol Co ( Table 1). The CoO nanostructures post their modification are referred to here as NP, NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS. The silicon content was determined by energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) of the modified samples with TEOS, TPES and TMCS as 31.4 mmol Si/mol Co, 33.4 mmol Si/mol Co and 29.2 mmol Si/mol Co, respectively. This corresponds to an average coverage of the Co(II)O NPs with silane of ca. 6.5–7 silanes per nm2. There are insignificant structural and size changes of cobalt oxide NPs post modification, as revealed by both TEM and XRD measurements (Fig. 1(a-d)). 3.2 Reduction of supported, modified cobalt NPs The influence of modification on the reducibility of the supported cobalt-based NPs was investigated using temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). Fig. 2 shows the TPR profiles of the (modified) CoO NPs. The reduction of Co in the unmodified NPs occurs in a single reduction step. with a peak maximum at 563 K. This reduction peak was best fitted using a unimolecular decay (assuming a first-order reaction kinetics for the reduction process) to obtain the activation energy,(Ea) of 45 ± 6 kJ/mol, and a pre-exponential factor (A) of 103.6±0.4 s−1). The TPR-profiles of the silane-modified Co NPs show the contributions of two distinct reduction processes, viz. a low temperature process attributable to the reduction of cobalt present as CoO and a slower process with a maximum rate at a higher temperature. The activation energy for the first reduction step in the TEOS-modified cobalt NPs increased to 59 ± 8 kJ/mol (A = 103.1±0.3 s−1; Tmax = 573 K), indicating that the modification of the NPS with TEOS retards the reduction of CoO to metallic Co, though only to a lower extent. The kinetic parameters for the reduction of the catalysts are shown in Table 2. The calculated activation energy for the first reduction step of Co(II)O to metallic cobalt in the nanoparticles modified with TPES or TMCS also increased slightly to 48 ± 15 kJ/mol (A = 103.4±0.8 s−1; Tmax = 565 K) and 52 ± 9 kJ/mol (A = 102.1±0.1 s−1; Tmax = 567 K), respectively. This observed, marginal shift in the reduction peaks, is similar to the peak shift we previously observed for the reduction of cobalt oxide chemically bonded to silica [10,14]. The change in the observed activation energy strongly suggests that silanes are bonded to the surface of cobalt (possibly in the form of siloxanes), since the reduction of ionic cobalt is hindered in these modified nanostructures. The TPR-profile of the CoO NPs modified with silanes also show evidence of a high temperature reduction process. The activation energy for this high temperature reduction process for sample modified with TEOS was determined to be 74 ± 11 kJ/mol with A = 104.1±0.1 s−1 if this process also follows a uni-molecular decay. The activation energy for this process for the TPES- and TMCS-modified samples was slightly higher at 77 ± 9 kJ/mol (A = 102.3±0.3s−1) and 81 ± 6 kJ/mol (10.1.1±0.1 s−1) respectively. The amount of cobalt associated with the high temperature peak increases in the order of NP-TEOS < NP-TPES < NP-TMCS, which may indicate that TPES and TMCS are more effective in bonding to CoO NPs, whereas TEOS results in the formation of some extraneous silica. This reduction peak is relatively sharp for the TEOS-modified cobalt NPs and broader for the TPES- and TMCS-modified cobalt NPs. A relatively sharp high temperature reduction peak implies the reduction of cobalt in a separate process with a higher activation energy; The broadness of the high temperature peak for NP-TPES and NP-TMCS in comparison to NP-TEOS has been attributed to the low pre-exponential factor for this process over these NPs. This might have been caused by a higher density of sites, to which the siloxane has been attached, resulting in less H2 available on the surface near to site to be reduced. The degree of reduction of the catalyst was determined by reducing the NP, NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS for 8 hrs at 573 K in H2, followed by cooling in Ar. These cobalt-based NPs were subsequently reduced in a temperature programmed manner by ramping up the temperature (ramp rate = 10 K/min) in a gas mixture of 5 % H2 in Ar up to 1173 K. The degree of reduction was computed from the relative H2 consumption of the reduced NP, NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS to that required for complete reduction of CoO (Table 2). The degree of reduction of the supported, reduced NP after reduction in H2 at 573 K for 8 hrs decreased upon modifying the Co(II)O-NPs. The change in the degree of reduction of NP-TEOS decreased from 95 % to 92 %, which correspond fortuitously to the Si/Co ratio of 31 mmol Si/mol Co. This would imply that cobalt directly attached to siloxane will not reduce under the applied conditions. However, it is anticipated that silicon in NPs modified with TEOS will not bond to cobalt in a 1:1 ratio [10], and some silica will be present as extraneous silica in the sample. It can thus be expected that not only the reducibility of cobalt directly bonded to siloxanes is decreased, but also the reducibility of cobalt in the vicinity of cobalt attached to siloxanes. This is confirmed by the further decrease in the degree of reduction to 90 % for NP-TPES and 87 % for NP-TMCS. A discrepancy in the activation energy trend between the first and the second reduction peaks is observed. The activation energy for the first reduction peak follows the trend NP, NP-TEOS > NP-TMCS > NP-TPES which is different from the trend observed for the second reduction peak (NP-TMCS > NP-TPES > NP-TEOS). This discrepancy can be explained by the initial surface interactions induced by the different silanes TEOS likely forms a more rigid and sterically hindered layer on the nanoparticle surface, resulting in a higher activation energy due to the difficulty of hydrogen penetration and initial reduction. TMCS, being smaller and less bulky compared to TPES, facilitates easier initial interaction with hydrogen, resulting in a lower activation energy for the first peak. TPES, despite being similar to TMCS in the degree of reduction, might have additional electronic effects due to its phenyl groups, which slightly lower the activation energy for the initial reduction but not as much as TMCS. Furthermore, the activation energy for the first reduction peaks reflects the ease of initial hydrogen uptake, significantly influenced by the properties of the surface silane layer. The varying degrees of surface coverage and hydrogen adsorption characteristics induced by the different silanes can contribute to the observed trends. TEOS, with its larger ethoxy groups, leads to a higher activation energy due to reduced surface accessibility, while TMCS and TPES modify the surface in ways that make initial hydrogen adsorption more favorable. 3.3 Characterization of reduced modified cobalt NPs The interaction between the silanes and cobalt surfaces may affect the metallic phase formed in the reduction with H2 at 573 K. Characterization of the crystalline structures of the reduced unmodified cobalt oxide NPs using PXRD ( Fig. 3) showed two characteristic diffraction lines for fcc-Co, centred at 51.8֯ and 62.5֯, which corresponded to (111) and (200) planes, respectively. The reduction of the TEOS-modified NPs also results in the formation of fcc-Co possibly because of the weak adsorption of TEOS on the cobalt surfaces. The reduction of both NP-TPES and NP-TMCS yielded the coexisting crystalline phases fcc-Co and hcp-Co in a ratio of ca. 60:40 as determined by Rietveld refinements and the respective crystallite sizes of each phase are shown in Table 1. Three broad reflections indexed to (100), (002) and (101) lattice reflections of the hcp-Co crystal structure, as well a decrease in the intensity of the reflection at 2Θ=62.5° ascribed to (200) plane in fcc-Co, can be observed in the XRD-pattern of the reduced TPES- and TMCS-modified Co NPs. The transition between fcc-Co and hcp-Co is of great interest and has been ascribed to the difference in the vibrational, magnetic, and electronic degrees of freedom in these structures [17], with especially the disappearance of the long range magnetic interactions in fcc-Co favouring the formation of the high temperature phase hcp-Co [18]. It may thus be speculated that bonding siloxanes to the cobalt surface perturbs the long range magnetic interactions and thus yield more hcp-Co. The surface electronic properties of the NP, NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS (reduced and passivated with CO2) were determined using X-ray photo-emission spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 4a shows Co 2p photoemission spectra of the model catalyst samples. The Co 2p photoemission peaks of the unmodified cobalt show spin-orbit peaks at 780.4 eV and 796.3 eV attributed to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 respectively. The ratio of the Co 2p3/2 to Co 2p1/2 was set to 2 during the fitting process. The spin-orbit splitting is determined to be 15.9 eV. The photoemission pattern also has two strong satellite peaks at 785.9 eV and 802.0 eV. The intensity of the satellite peaks in this spectrum relative to the main peaks agrees with previous work which shows a proportionality between the intensity of the 2+ component and the satellite structure for a sample containing CoO [19]. These observations indicate that cobalt on/near the surface in the passivated reduced catalyst exists in the form of CoO. For the silanes-modified NPs, the photo-emission features in the cobalt range appears asymmetric, as shown in Fig. 4a. The Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 contributions can be deconvoluted into two main components (Co 2p3/2 at ca. 780.5 eV and ∼778.6 eV and Co 2p1/2 at ca. 796.4 eV and ∼794.2 eV). The corresponding lower binding energy of the extra component is less than that of Co3+ and therefore cannot be attributed to the further oxidation of Co(II)O to Co3O4 [20]. We have previously ascribed this photoemission peak to divalent cobalt in contact with silica through a Co-O-Si linkage [14]. The occurrence of this extra photoemission line at a lower energy than that of Co2+ in Co(II)O may signify a higher electron concentration on cobalt for these cobalt species. The position of this photoemission peak does not vary significantly with respect to the modifying agents: it appears at 778.6 eV, 778.4 eV and 778.5 eV for the NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS respectively ( Table 3). This may indicate that the attached silanes increase the electron density around cobalt to which they are bonded, to about the same extent. The spin orbit splitting of these photoemission peaks is ca. 15.7 eV for all the modified NPs. This value is about 0.2 eV lower than the spin orbit splitting of Co(II)O which remains constant at 15.9–16.0 eV. The photoemission profiles of the Si 2p indicate the presence of silicon on the cobalt NP surfaces. It may be expected that a shift in the Si 2p photoemission occurs in the opposite direction as opposed to the shift in the Co 2p peak if indeed the electron density moves across silica and cobalt boundary. Fig. 4b shows the Si 2p XPS features of the modified NPs. These photoemission peaks were referenced against the photoemission peaks of SiO2 Stöber spheres. The Si 2p photoemissions of Stöber spheres can be deconvoluted into two major components: at 103.6 eV due to SiO2 photoemissions and 101.4 eV due to Si-OH photoemissions. The ratio of the Si 2p photoemission peak attributed to SiO2 and the Si 2p photoemission attributed to the Si-O suboxides is 4. Similar photoemissions peaks are observed for the NP-TEOS. The ratio of the photoemissions due to Si-O-Si relative to those due to Si-OH changes significantly in favour of photoemission Si-OH for silicon in NP-TEOS. This may be due to increased number of Si-OH termination possibly due to the presence of smaller silicate islands on the cobalt surface upon modification with TEOS [10]. An additional photoemission peak at 105.5 eV is observed for this sample, which may be attributed to the photoemissions due to Co-O-Si suggesting that the interaction of cobalt with silica occurs via Co-O-Si bridges. In contrast, the Si-O-Si and Si-OH photoemissions peaks are not present for NP-TPES or NP-TMCS. However, entirely new peaks are observed. For these NP-TPES and NP-TMCS, different peaks are observed at ∼100 eV, which can be attributed to the photoemissions due to O-Si-C bonds (Table 3). The appearance of these photoemissions may indicate that the silanes are present with the hydrocarbon moiety on the samples. The observed photoemission line may be ascribed to the presence of O-Si-R at around 100.5 eV (where R is of the methyl groups) and 100.3 eV (where R is of the phenyl groups). The phenyl groups will shift electrons more towards silicon than methyl groups due to the resonance effect of the electrons in the phenyl ring thus resulting in a slight downward shift in the binding energy. In addition, the photoemission peak at 102.6 eV is ascribed to Si-H photoemissions [20]. The Si-H bond may be formed by the reaction of phenyl silyl groups with H2 producing hydro-silane Si-H species (reaction 1). One may be tempted to ascribe this peak to Si bonded to partially hydrogenated phenyl groups. However, this peak is not significantly different from the peak observed at 102.7 eV for the reduced NP-TMCS sample which is ascribable to Si-H photoemissions [20] which may be formed as represented by reaction 2. The ratio of the Si bonded to triphenyl silyl groups relative to the amount of Si bonded to H2 (Si-C/Si-H) is 1.3 and the ratio of the Si-C/Si-H photoemissions is 1 for NP-TMCS This suggests that some of the phenyl/methyl groups are lost during reduction. (1) -O-Si-(Ph)3 + 2H2 --> O-SiH + 3 C6H6 (2) -O-Si-(CH3)3+ 2H2 --> O-SiH + 3CH4 As expected, the C 1 s photoemissions were also present in the XPS spectra of the samples indicating the presence of carbon on the samples (Fig. 4c). The C 1 s photoemissions from the unmodified cobalt NPs can be deconvoluted into three peaks with maxima at 284.7 eV, 285.5 eV, and 286.5 eV. The photoemission peak at 284.7 eV is ascribed to non-oxygenated carbon atoms (CC) [21], probably from extraneous carbon. The peak at 285.5 eV is ascribed to the presence of C-O while the peak at 286.5 eV arises due to the presence of CO bonds on the surface [22,23] e.g., originating from CO2 which was used to passivate the cobalt NPs after reduction. A similar set of peaks is observed for the sample modified with TEOS. No additional C 1 s photoemissions were observed, indicating the breaking down of TEOS during the reduction process. The XPS of reduced and passivated NP-TPES resulted in one additional photoemission line centred at 283.0 eV. This photoemission peak may arise from the C-Si species [24], The intensity of the peak at 284.7 eV relative to the Si 2p photoemissions increases drastically for the NP-TPES from 1.1 (NP-TEOS) to 13.4 (NP-TPES). This increase is due to the presence of carbon originating from the phenyl silyl groups [21]. The expected ratio of carbon to silicon in triphenyl ethoxy silane is 20. Elimination of the ethoxy group in bonding of TPES to Co(II)O surface would reduce this to 18. It can thus be deduced that not only ethoxy groups have been removed from the silane, but also some of the phenyl groups. The evaluation of the XPS spectrum of the NP-TMCS shows a photo-emission line centred at 283.5 eV, which may be attributed to C-Si. The Calkyl to Si ratio for this sample is about 1.8 as determined from the photoemission peak at 284.7 eV relative to the photo-emission peaks corresponding to Si 2p. The ratio is less than the expected Calkyl /Si ratio of 3 in trimethyl chlorosilane implying the loss of carbon during the reduction process. The bonding of the silanes in the modified cobalt NPs after reduction was investigated using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The infrared spectrum of the reduced unmodified Co(II)O NPs shows bands in three different regions, viz. absorption bands at 1600–1640 cm−1, 2800–3000 cm−1 and 3300–3500 cm−1 ( Fig. 5). The absorption bands in the regions of 1600–1640 cm−1 and 3300–3500 cm−1 are ascribed to the surface O-H bending and stretching vibrations [25,26], respectively while bands in the regions of 2800–2940 cm−1 can be ascribed to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching frequencies of the -CH bonds. The infrared spectrum of the reduced NP-TEOS shows additional absorption bands at 460 cm−1, 800 cm−1, and 1100 cm−1. These three bands are characteristic of extraneous silica. The band at 800 cm−1 can be attributed to the in-plane Si-O-Si bending vibration [27], The bands at 460 cm−1 and 1100 cm−1 are ascribed to the asymmetric stretching of the Si-O-Si of the amorphous SiO4 tetrahedron [28,29], The absorption bands in the region of 2900–3000 cm−1 are attributed to the C-H vibrations. These bands are relatively small, which may indicate that the some de-ethoxylation occurred during the reduction process. The infrared spectrum of the reduced NP-TPES appears to contain some bands of medium and strong intensity which are typical of Si-C6H5 bond with the following frequencies: 903 cm−1, 1120 cm−1, 2170 cm−1. A broad shoulder appears at ad band at 1020 cm−1 which may be ascribed to the vibrations associated with a Co-O-Si. However, the in-plane C-H deformation vibrations in the phenyl ring that usually appear between 1000 cm−1 and 1250 cm−1 may not be ruled out [30,31]. In addition, the symmetric and asymmetric C-H stretch vibration of C-H in the benzene ring are seen at 3050 cm−1 [32]. This suggests that TPES hardly or not decomposes during the reduction in H2 at 573 K. The FTIR spectrum of the reduced NP-TMCS is characterized by distinctive absorption bands related to Si-C stretching vibrations of the Si-CH3 appearing at 835 cm−1 and 755 cm−1 is ascribable to -CH3 rocking and Si-C stretching [30–32]. Abroad shoulder observed at 1018 cm−1, which could imply the existence of monodentate Co-O-Si species, akin to those identified in analogous iron-silica species [12]. This bond may be formed through the reaction of TMCS with the surface hydroxyl of the oxidised cobalt surface. The bands at 1170 cm−1 and 1250 cm−1 are due to the deformation vibration of the CH3-Si bonds and confirm the presence of residual trimethyl silyl species on the sample even after reduction in H2 at 573 K for 8 hrs. Hydrogen (H2) chemisorption measurements were conducted to determine the dispersion in all the catalysts. The degree of reduction of the catalysts decreases slightly due to the modification of NPs with different silanes ( Table 4). The modification of the NPs with silanes decreased the H2-uptake per unit mass of cobalt on both the fresh and spent catalysts. This decrease in the H2-uptake relative to the uptake of the catalyst without modification (NP) is lowest for the NP-TEOS and the largest for the NP-TPES. This decrease may be related to the occupation of some sites for H2 adsorption by siloxane/silica. A decrease in the H2-uptake could also have been expected if the modified cobalt NPs would have experienced sintering during the reduction process at 573 K. However, modifying NPs with silane species is thought to reduce the likelihood of sintering since there is no much difference in the a mount of H2 uptake between the fresh and the spent catalyst (Table 4). The decrease in the H2-uptake on the NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS relative to the sample NP may be used to estimate the amount of cobalt covered by siloxane/silica (ΔnCo,cov), as cobalt covered by these surface cobalt atoms are no longer accessible to H2. The amount of silicon present in the sample relative to the amount of cobalt covered by silica in the sample NP-TEOS was 20 mol Si/ ΔnCo,cov implying the formation of silica islands rather than atomically dispersed silane/silicate species on the surface.[10,14] The ratios determined for both the reduced NP-TPES and NP-TMCS are much lower at 3.6 and 4.2 mol Si/ mol ΔnCo,cov, respectively. This suggests a high dispersion of the resulting silicon containing species upon modifying the Co(II)O NPs with TPES and TMCS. Temperature programmed desorption of carbon monoxide (CO-TPD) was used on the reduced, supported NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS to evaluate the dissociative chemisorption of CO and its subsequent desorption. As summarized in Table 5, the total amount of CO adsorbed prior to CO-TPD decreased by approximately 16–27 % on the silane-modified cobalt catalysts in comparison to the unmodified cobalt nanoparticles. This is consistent with similar decreasing trends observed in the H2-uptake (see Table 4). These findings indicate that the modification of Co(II)O NPs with silanes results in a decrease in the uptake of both H2 and CO on the reduced catalysts. This might arise due to blockage of cobalt active site geometries required for the dissociative adsorption of CO and H2 by the silicon containing species or by sintering of the resulting metal particles. The expected ratio of CO adsorbed to H2 required to form a monolayer is 2:1 assuming dissociative adsorption of H2 and associative adsorption of CO without repulsive lateral interactions in the adsorbate layer. The experimentally determined ratio is 1.5±0.1 mol CO/mol H2, most indicating that full monolayer coverage with CO is not obtained. This may be ascribed to the lateral interactions occurring between the CO molecules upon adsorption [33]. The CO-TPD profiles of all these cobalt-based catalysts show two distinct desorption peaks, viz. a low temperature peak (located at 640–750 K) attributable to desorption of molecularly adsorbed CO and a high temperature peak (located at 950–1100 K) assigned to desorption of dissociated CO ( Fig. 6) [34,35]. For the unmodified sample, NP, the low temperature peak appears as a single peak at ca. 730 K. The single peak from the molecularly adsorbed CO on all the NPs suggests that the adsorption sites for the molecularly adsorbed CO may be similar. It is noted that this desorption peaks occur at relatively high temperatures compared to the previously recorded desorption temperatures of CO on the cobalt surfaces [36]. This shift to higher temperatures is consistent with previous reports by Zagli and Falconer [37], and this observation was attributed to the re-adsorption of desorbed CO. We note here that the amount of catalyst loaded into the reactor for this temperature programmed desorption experiments is high (1.0 g; 50 mL (NTP)/min), which will increase the likelihood of CO re-adsorption. Furthermore, the peak due to the desorption of dissociatively adsorbed CO occurs as a broad feature with a leading-edge peaking at ca. 1000 K. This can be deconvoluted into 2–3 subpeaks, suggesting CO adsorption taking place on multiple geometric surface sites. For the unmodified sample, the low temperature desorption peak accounts for 0.10 mmol of CO and the high temperature desorption peak accounts for 0.08 mmol CO (COdiss/COass= 0.8) For the sample modified with TEOS a very similar CO-TPD profile is observed. However, the low temperature peak becomes narrower and shifts from 730 K to 739 K. The shift towards higher desorption temperatures may suggest an increase in CO adsorption strength. This change in the strength of adsorption may facilitate ease of the dissociation of CO. This can be seen in the ratio of dissociatively adsorbed CO to molecularly adsorbed CO (COdiss/COass) which changes significantly on the TEOS-modified catalysts in favour of dissociatively adsorbed CO to 1.5. This implies facilitated CO dissociation in the presence of the TEOS/silica species on the cobalt surface. A shift to higher desorption temperatures is seen on the high temperature desorption peak from ca. 1000 K to 1040 K. This may indicate a reduced rate of recombination of C* and O* on the surface. The sample modified with TPES (NP-TPES) shows a remarkably different CO-TPD profile from the one of NP with a shift of the low desorption temperature peak to higher temperatures suggesting an increase in the CO adsorption strength. The ratio of dissociatively adsorbed CO to molecularly adsorbed CO (COass) for NP-TPES is 2.5. However, the higher temperature desorption peaks are shifted to lower temperatures suggesting a more facile recombination rate of C* and O*. The CO-TPD profile for NP-TMCS has a low temperature peak appearing at the same temperature as for the unmodified sample. However, the high temperature desorption peak is shifted to even lower temperatures of ca. 950 K with the ratio of dissociatively adsorbed CO to molecularly adsorbed CO (COdiss/COass) sitting at 1.8. CO tends to withdraw electrons upon adsorbing on cobalt surface as electron rich surfaces donate more electrons to the CO 2 π obirtals [38]. Therefore, electron donating ligands (e.g. TPES or TMCS) attached to the surface of cobalt may result in weakened CO bond, thus facilitating the dissociation of CO. Hence, modification of cobalt with electron donating silanes yields a larger fraction of dissociatively adsorbed CO with more dissociation observed for the modification with TPES. This may arise due to higher electron donor effect of the phenyl groups caused by the resonating electrons around the molecule relative to the methyl groups. 3.4 Fischer-Tropsch synthesis The supported catalysts were activated in H2 at 573 K for 16 hours. The catalytic activity of the catalysts was tested at 493 K, 20 bar, (H2/CO)inlet = 2 and FCO,0/W = 5.23 mmol/(min.gCo) and it remained constant between 16 and 44 hrs on-line ( Fig. 7a). The reduced unmodified catalyst (NP) was used as a control experiment. Only a modest conversion of 3.5 % was obtained after 16 hrs on stream. Between 24 and 44 hours the activity declined to ca. 2.4 %. (i.e. 45 % decline in activity) The silane-modified cobalt catalysts displayed superior catalytic activity relative to the unmodified cobalt catalyst as was previously demonstrated for the performance of reduced Co3O4 modified with TEOS [10]. The CO conversion over NP-TEOS, NP-TPES and NP-TMCS are 26 %, 33 % and 22 %, respectively. The outstanding catalytic activities highlight the important roles played upon modifying the surfaces of cobalt(II)oxide catalyst precursor with silanes. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of the modified samples remains stable in terms of CO-conversion, and selectivity over the testing period of the catalysts of 44 hours infers that the catalysts do not undergo significant structural degradation, which would impair their function. Turnover frequencies (TOFs) were determined to account for the differences in the metal surface area (it is noted that the metal dispersion did not change much due to the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis – see Table 4). The TOF obtained over NP-TEOS is 11 times larger than the that of the NP. Both catalyst systems contain cobalt as fcc-Co (Fig. 3). The differences in TOFs between these two types of catalysts may be attributed to a change in the predominance of the crystal planes exposed in the reduced catalyst and/or a chemical effect [39,40] due to the presence of silicate islands on the surface [10,14]. The reduced TPES- and TMCS-modified catalysts consisted of a large amount of hcp-Co (Fig. 3). Metallic hcp-Co has been previously reported to be catalytically more active than an fcc-Co in CO hydrogenation [41–43]. These catalytic activity differences were attributed to a lower barrier for CO dissociation over some facets of hcp-Co compared to dominant facets on fcc-Co. The improved catalytic activity of NP-TPES may be partially attributed to the presence of hcp-Co phase with anisotropic properties. The TPES-modified catalyst outperformed the TMCS-modified catalyst. It is tempting to attribute this to small traces of chlorine on NP-TMCS [44,45]. However, the presence of chlorine could not be confirmed in the catalyst, suggesting it might be less than 0.01 wt%, the standard detection limit of EDS [46], as chlorine should be easily removed at temperatures above 473 K [10,14]. The change in the activity is thought to originate from the differences in the propensity for CO-dissociation. The modified materials showed different propensity for CO-dissociation in the CO-TPD, and different catalytic activities in CO hydrogenation. Fig. 7b shows a reasonable correlation between the obtained turnover frequency as a measure for the catalytic activity and the amount of dissociated CO relative to the amount of molecularly adsorbed CO, as determined from CO-TPD. The obtained correlation supports the supposition that enhanced activity may be related to enhanced CO-dissociation in the modified samples and thus enhanced catalytic activity. 3.5 Selectivity analysis A change in electronic properties may not only change the rate of CO consumption but also the product selectivity as evidenced by e.g., methane selectivity, chain growth probability and olefin to paraffin selectivity. To untangle the promotional influence of silanes on cobalt from the effects of CO conversion levels on methane selectivity, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis experiments were conducted at similar CO conversion maintained at ca. 23 % for all catalysts attained by controlling the feed flowrate. While the modification of Co(II)O with TEOS increases the TOF by ca. 10-fold, the product distribution does not appear to be affected. The methane, C2–4 and C5+ selectivity of NP and NP-TEOS are similar. The product distribution obtained over NP-TPES and NP-TMCS is quite different from NP and NP-TEOS (see Table 6), which is attributed to structural and electronic effects. The conversion obtained over NP-TPES and NP-TMCS is similar to the conversion obtained over NP-TEOS and hence, changes in selectivity cannot be attributed to difference in the level of conversion [47–49]. The methane selectivity over NP-TMCS and NP-TPES is rather high at ca. 32–34 %, considering the presence of hcp-Co phase within the catalyst. The methane selectivity over hcp-Co phase, when prepared using a reduction-carburization-reduction (RCR) route, is usually lower than the methane selectivity obtained over an fcc-Co phase structure [50]. However, it should be highlighted that the propensity for carbon hydrogenation yielding methane is facet dependent and is favoured fcc-Co compared to some facets of hcp-Co, but this is not true for all the crystal facets [51]. Hence, methane selectivity is not only phase dependent but also depends on the exposed surfaces. The modification of cobalt NPs with TPES or TMCS may have resulted in a different morphology of the reduced particles compared to those obtained via carburization. The observed trend for the change in the chain growth probability upon modifying cobalt with silanes mirrors the observed trend of the methane selectivity. Methane is thought to be formed via the consecutive hydrogenation C* → CH* → CH2* → CH3* → CH4. An increase in the methane selectivity (in C-%) implies an increased likelihood that carbon originally present in CO ends up in methane (in contrast to the methane selectivity in mol-%, which represents the probability of desorption of the chain starter as methane). Hence, an increased methane selectivity implies that the fraction of carbon being used in the chain growth process decreases. Therefore, an increased methane selectivity is thought to be associated with a decreased availability of carbon incorporated into growing chains and thus decreasing the rate of chain growth (and thus the chain growth probability). 1-Olefins are the major primary products of the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [49,52]. which may undergo secondary reactions such as secondary olefin hydrogenation or double bond isomerisation. The extent to which these product compounds undergo secondary reactions can be seen from the characteristic carbon number dependency of the olefin carbon [53] as shown in Fig. 8. The 1-olefin/paraffin ratio obtained over the unmodified cobalt NPs is low, indicating rapid secondary conversion of the primarily formed 1-olefins. The 1-olefin/paraffin ratio obtained over the silane-modified catalysts is much higher, implying the inhibition of the secondary conversion of these product compounds. It can be noted that the modification of cobalt oxide NPs with various silanes affects the 1-olefin/paraffin ratio in a given carbon number fraction to a similar extent. Various reasons may be put forward for these observations: the presence of more hcp-Co phases in both TPES- and TMCS-modified catalysts, which may enhance CO-dissociation and thus increase the coverage of the surface with carbon, which may inhibit re-adsorption of olefins. Furthermore, the structures derived from adsorbed silanes in the reduced catalyst may change the reactivity of cobalt towards olefins. 4 Conclusions The modification of the surfaces of Co(II)O NPs with different silanes is a novel method to create catalytically active nanomaterials. Here, we demonstrate that the adsorption of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) on Co(II)O NPs results in the formation of surface silica after reduction, whilst the adsorption of triphenylethoxysilane (TPES) and trimethylchorosilane (TMCS) result in the presence of alkylated silane surface species after reduction with H2. Reduction of Co(II)O and TEOS-modified Co(II)O NPs in H2 at 573 K resulted in the formation of only fcc-Co phase whereas modification of Co(II)O with either TPES or TMCS facilitated the formation of mixtures of hcp-Co and fcc-Co during the reduction in H2 at 573 K. This may partly explain the difference in catalytic performance of the catalyst. However, the modification of cobalt with TEOS, TPES and TMCS results with an electron-rich cobalt surface, as shown by XPS measurements. This weakens the CO bond in adsorbed CO thus facilitating CO dissociation. This is confirmed by the CO-TPD study which shows that upon modification the amount of dissociatively adsorbed CO increases. This may explain the observed increased rate of CO-conversion. Moreover, the electron-rich cobalt surface may facilitate a quicker desorption of products, and this may explain the reduced chain growth probability and increase olefin content when cobalt is modified with alkylated ligands. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt oxide (CoO) nanoparticles (NPs) were modified with different silanes (tetraethoxysilane – TEOS, triphenyl ethoxysilane – TPES, or trimethyl chlorosilane - TMCS) by dispersing the as-synthesized CoO NPs in n-hexane solutions containing the silanes. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) confirmed the presence of these silanes on the cobalt surfaces even after reduction in hydrogen (H2) at 573 K. Modifying CoO-NPs with TEOS resulted in face-centred cubic (fcc)-cobalt phase upon reduction whereas TPES or TMCS modification induced a mixture of hexagonal close-packed (hcp)- and fcc-cobalt phases. The modification of cobalt surfaces with the silanes alters the adsorption properties of carbon monoxide (CO) on the catalytically active sites. Furthermore, temperature programmed desorption of CO (CO-TPD) showed that the amount of dissociatively adsorbed CO relative to amount of associatively adsorbed CO increases on silane-modified cobalt surfaces, which correlates with an improved rate of CO conversion in the Fischer-Tropsch CO hydrogenation.
